quotes.quote: Go to any Shinto temple in Japan and you'll see it: a simple stand from which hang hundreds of wooden postcard-size plaques with a colorful image on one side and, on the other, densely scribbled Japanese characters in black felt-tip pen, pleas to the gods for help or succor.

Shinto is still, in a manner of speaking, the soul of Japan, and even young Westernised Japanese who take no part in its manifold ritual, are conditioned, as their parents and grandparents were, by its fundamental characteristics.
Shinto is essentially a religion of gratitude and love.
Sincerity is the single virtue that binds divinity and man in one.

Shinto is a way that is practised every morning and evening, in the acts of daily life, by every individual from the emperor to the common peopleâ€¦  there is nothing within human life that does not belong to Shinto.
The inside of a house or apartment after decluttering has much in common with a Shinto shrine... a place where there are no unnecessary things, and our thoughts become clear.
Shinto lies at the root of the whole of Japanese culture.
The heart of the person before you is a mirror. See there your own form.
Japanese mind is synonymous with Shinto mind.

A mirror has a clean light that reflects everything as it is. It symbolizes the stainless mind of the kami, and at the same time is regarded as a sacred symbolic embodiment of the fidelity of the worshipper towards the kami.
The nature of Shinto speaks to our human natureâ€¦.   Shinto speaks to us, to something in us which is deep and permanent.
To be fully alive is to have an aesthetic perception of life because a major part of the world's goodness lies in its often unspeakable beauty.
Even the wishes of a small ant reach heaven.
For Shinto, at root, is a religion not of sermons but of awe: which is a sentiment that may or may not produce words, but in either case goes beyond them.
Retribution for good or ill is as sure as the shadow after substance.
